title: Hamish MacInnes
text:
Hamish MacInnes (7 July 1930 – 22 November 2020) was a Scottish mountaineer, explorer, mountain search and rescuer, and author. He has been described as the "father of modern <a href="mountain%20rescue">mountain rescue</a> in <a href="Scotland">Scotland</a>". He is credited with inventing the first all-metal <a href="ice-axe">ice-axe</a> and an eponymous lightweight foldable alloy stretcher called "MacInnes stretcher", widely used in mountain and helicopter rescue. He was a mountain safety advisor to a number of major films, including "<a href="Monty%20Python%20and%20the%20Holy%20Grail">Monty Python and the Holy Grail</a>," "<a href="The%20Eiger%20Sanction%20%28film%29">The Eiger Sanction</a>" and "<a href="The%20Mission%20%281986%20film%29">The Mission</a>." His 1972 "International Mountain Rescue Handbook" is considered a manual in the mountain search and rescue discipline.
Early life.
MacInnes was born in <a href="Gatehouse%20of%20Fleet">Gatehouse of Fleet</a>, in the historical county of <a href="Kirkcudbrightshire">Kirkcudbrightshire</a> in <a href="Galloway">Galloway</a>, Scotland, on 7 July 1930. His father's surname was McInnes, but Hamish, (according to his obituary in "The Times") "later adopted the more distinctive Scottish spelling of the family name". He was the youngest child amongst five siblings. He had three sisters and a brother who was eighteen years older than Hamish. His father served in the Chinese police in Shanghai, then returned to join the <a href="British%20Army">British Army</a> and the <a href="Canadian%20Army">Canadian Army</a> during World War I. He had served with <a href="National%20service">National service</a>, shortly after the Second World War, with a deployment in Austria.
Mountaineering and mountain rescue.
MacInnes was exposed to mountaineering at a very early age and by the age of 16, he had already climbed the <a href="Matterhorn">Matterhorn</a>. He had also built a motor car from scratch at the age of 17. In 1953, when he was 23, he made an attempt to scale <a href="Mount%20Everest">Mount Everest</a>, with his friend <a href="John%20Crabbe%20Cunningham">John Crabbe Cunningham</a> and had almost made it before <a href="Edmund%20Hillary">Edmund Hillary</a> and <a href="Tenzing%20Norgay">Tenzing Norgay</a> scaled the mountain. He went on to complete the first winter ascent of <a href="Crowberry%20Ridge">Crowberry Ridge Direct</a> and of Raven's Gully on <a href="Buachaille%20Etive%20M%C3%B2r">Buachaille Etive Mòr</a> in the <a href="Scottish%20Highlands">Scottish Highlands</a>, with <a href="Chris%20Bonington">Chris Bonington</a> in 1953. He was also a part of the group that scaled the Bonatti Pillar on the <a href="Aiguille%20du%20Dru">Aiguille du Dru</a>, a mountain on the <a href="Mont%20Blanc">Mont Blanc</a> massif of the <a href="French%20Alps">French Alps</a>. He performed this feat with a fractured skull, which he suffered after being hit by a rockfall.
He is noted for bringing many innovations to mountaineering equipment, including designing the first all-metal <a href="ice%20axe">ice axe</a>. He is credited with introducing the short ice <a href="Ice%20tool">axe</a> and hammer with inclined picks for Scottish winter work in the early 1960s. He also pioneered the exploration of the <a href="Glen%20Coe">Glencoe</a> cliffs for winter work with the Glencoe School of Winter Climbing and led the area's <a href="mountain%20rescue">mountain rescue</a> team from 1961. He is recognised as having developed modern mountain rescue in Scotland, setting up the <a href="Search%20and%20Rescue%20Dog%20Association">Search and Rescue Dog Association</a> with his wife in 1965 and the <a href="Scottish%20Avalanche%20Information%20Service">Scottish Avalanche Information Service</a> in 1988. He invented the eponymous MacInnes stretcher, a lightweight and specialised folding alloy stretcher, which is used for rescues worldwide.
IN 1972 he was part of an 11-strong team that attempted to be the first to ascent the southwest face of Everest, but their expedition did not reach the summit due bad weather. In 1975, MacInnes was deputy leader to Bonington's <a href="1975%20British%20Mount%20Everest%20Southwest%20Face%20expedition">Mount Everest Southwest Face expedition</a>, which included <a href="Dougal%20Haston">Dougal Haston</a> and <a href="Doug%20Scott">Doug Scott</a>. He had been tasked with designing equipment for that expedition but after being caught in an avalanche high on the mountain was unable to continue. He went on to scale the overhanging prow of <a href="Mount%20Roraima">Mount Roraima</a> in the mountainous regions around Brazil, Venezuela and Guyana.
Although never an official member, MacInnes climbed extensively with the Creagh Dhu, Glasgow-based climbing club as well as with the rival Aberdeen clubs. He joined forces with <a href="Tom%20Patey">Tom Patey</a> to make the first winter traverse of the <a href="Cuillin">Cuillin</a> Ridge on <a href="Skye">Skye</a>.
He was involved with a number of films, as climber, climbing double and safety officer, including "<a href="The%20Eiger%20Sanction%20%28film%29">The Eiger Sanction</a>" and "<a href="The%20Mission%20%281986%20film%29">The Mission</a>." He also worked on the 1975 film "<a href="The%20Eiger%20Sanction%20%28film%29">The Eiger Sanction</a>" and the 1986 film "<a href="The%20Mission%20%281986%20film%29">The Mission</a>". He was part of the production team for the 1975 film "<a href="Monty%20Python%20and%20the%20Holy%20Grail">Monty Python and the Holy Grail</a>". He served as mountaineering consultant, built the film's "bridge of death" and became friends with star <a href="Michael%20Palin">Michael Palin</a>.
He wrote many books on mountaineering, including the "International Mountain Rescue Handbook" (1972), which is regarded as the standard manual worldwide in the mountain search and rescue discipline, and "Call-out: A climber's tales of mountain rescue in Scotland" (1973), his account of his experiences leading the Glencoe Rescue team.
MacInnes acquired a number of nicknames within the mountaineering community, including the affectionate "Old Fox of Glencoe", "The Fox of Glencoe" and "MacPiton".
In 1994 MacInnes resigned his position as leader of the Glencoe Mountain Rescue team, over a decision taken by his colleagues to let the <a href="BBC%20Programmes">BBC</a> make a documentary based on their work. However, the decision changed and he returned as leader.
Awards and honours.
MacInnes was awarded a <a href="British%20Empire%20Medal">British Empire Medal</a> in the <a href="1962%20New%20Year%20Honours">1962 New Year Honours</a>. He was appointed an <a href="Officer%20of%20the%20Order%20of%20the%20British%20Empire">Officer of the Order of the British Empire</a> (OBE) for services to mountaineering and mountain rescue in Scotland in the <a href="1979%20New%20Year%20Honours">1979 New Year Honours</a>. He received an Honorary Doctorate from <a href="Heriot-Watt%20University">Heriot-Watt University</a> in 1992, <a href="University%20of%20Stirling">University of Stirling</a> in 1997 and <a href="University%20of%20Dundee">University of Dundee</a> in 2004. In 2007 he was awarded honorary fellowship of the <a href="Royal%20Scottish%20Geographical%20Society">Royal Scottish Geographical Society</a>. He was inducted into the <a href="Scottish%20Sports%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Scottish Sports Hall of Fame</a> in 2003 and received the Scottish Award for Excellence in Mountain Culture in 2008. In 2016 he was presented with the Chancellor’s Medal from the University of the Highlands and Islands.
In 2018 a documentary film was produced for <a href="BBC%20Scotland">BBC Scotland</a>, titled "Final Ascent:The Legend of Hamish MacInnes". Introduced by his friend, <a href="Michael%20Palin">Michael Palin</a>, it recounts the story of MacInnes's life and achievements, and how he used archive footage, his photographs and his many books to "recover his memories and rescue himself".    
Personal life.
MacInnes lived in <a href="Glen%20Coe">Glen Coe</a> for many years. Until 1998, he resided at "Allt Na Reigh", a cottage within the glen that was subsequently purchased by English media personality, <a href="Jimmy%20Savile">Jimmy Savile</a>. MacInnes later said that he was hoodwinked by Savile, and pleaded that the house, which was believed not to have been the scene of any of the offences for which Savile subsequently became infamous, not be demolished.
Illness and death.
In 2014, MacInnes suffered a <a href="urinary%20tract%20infection">urinary tract infection</a> which, initially undiagnosed, rendered him severely confused and suffering from delirium. He was <a href="Involuntary%20commitment">sectioned</a> into Belford psychiatric hospital in the Scottish Highlands. From there he made multiple attempts to escape, including scaling up the outside of the hospital to stand on its roof. After around five years the infection was diagnosed and treated. MacInnes recovered, though he lost memories of his adventuring career that he sought to rebuild by reading his accounts of them.
He died on 22 November 2020, aged 90, at his home in Glen Coe. Writing on his death, the Scottish daily "<a href="The%20Scotsman">The Scotsman</a>" said, "No one man has done more to help put in place the network of emergency response efforts designed to keep climbers from harm’s way, and it seems that MacInnes took just as much pleasure in helping to rescue people as he did in making record-breaking ascents."
